chemical_disease_relation_menu.desc: The chemical has some type of relation to the disease.

children.desc: The chemical worsens or exacerbates the disease in any manner.
The chemical improves or treats the disease in any manner.

Symptoms are defined as subjective physical or mental manifestations of a disease; examples include stomachache, lower-back pain, and fatigue. Signs are defined as objective manifestations of a disease; examples include high white blood cell count or bloody stool.
Causes of disease include infectious, non-communicable/non-transferable, or lifestyle causes.
Administration of the drug increases chances of getting the disease. Also considered 'adverse effects'.

chemical_disease_relation_menu.desc: There is no relationship between the chemical and disease.

gene_disease_relation_menu.desc: the gene is related to the disease in some manner.

children.desc: gene expression is the process by which information from a gene is used in the synthesis of a functional gene product. When gene expression is altered, gene expression is either increased or decreased.
less gene product (mRNA, protein, or microRNAs) is produced than normal.
more gene product (mRNA, protein, or microRNAs) is produced than normal.
gene regulation is the process of turning genes on or off.

Gene mutations or aberrations are permanent changes in the gene DNA sequence, differing from the sequence found in most people. Mutations range in size; they can affect anywhere from a single DNA base pair to a large piece of a chromosome that includes multiple genes.

A mutation in which a part of a chromosome or a sequence of DNA is lost is considered a deletion mutation. Deletion mutations are sometimes known as deficiencies, gene deletions, or simply 'deletions.'
A duplication mutation is when any region of DNA is generated/duplicated or abnormally copied during molecular evolution from within a gene region.
An insertion mutation changes the number of DNA bases in a gene by adding a piece of DNA.
When a chromosome segment is 'clipped' out, turned upside down, and reinserted back into the chromosome, it is considered an inversion mutation.
When one base pair is replaced by a different base pair it is considered a substitution mutation.

children.text: and post-translational modifications are associated with
children.desc: Translation is protein synthesis. When changes are made to a protein during or after translation, it is considered a post-translational modification.

gene_disease_relation_menu.desc: The gene does not relate to the disease.

chemical_disease_general_definitions.desc: a substance with a distinct molecular composition, including, but not limited to, brand name, generic or illegal drugs, chemical elements (Eg-oxygen), molecules.
signs are defined as objective manifestations of a disease; examples include high white blood cell count or blood in the stool.
symptoms are defined as subjective physical or mental manifestations of a disease; examples include stomachache, back pain, headache, and fatigue.

gene_disease_general_definitions.desc: A molecular unit of heredity in an organism, and is usually referred to in biomedical literature by their gene name, gene symbol, or both.
usually a protein, mRNA or microRNA that is encoded by the gene and will sometimes have the same name/symbol as the gene.
a particular abnormal, pathological condition that affects part or all of an organism.
a specific category of similar but different diseases.
